title: 112_hr6388
content: Increased enforcement under the Horse Protection Act. The Horse Protection Act is amended to include a definition of "action device" as any device that encircles the lower leg of a horse and can cause friction or strike the hoof. The amendment also includes provisions for enforcement, including the sponsoring organization and event manager. The Horse Protection Act is amended to define "participate" in horse shows, exhibitions, or sales. This includes activities like transporting horses, giving instructions to exhibitors, and being present in restricted areas. The Horse Protection Act is amended to include financing participation in horse shows, exhibitions, or auctions. The findings highlight the negative impact of soring horses on competition and sales. The Horse Protection Act is amended to address inadequate inspection programs for preventing horse soring at shows and exhibitions. The Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture has found the current program insufficient, and violations of the Act persist despite regulations in place. The Horse Protection Act is amended to disqualify sore horses from being shown or exhibited for specific periods, with increasing penalties for repeat offenses. Subsection (b) is updated to replace "appointed" with "licensed". Subsection (c) is removed and replaced with a new subsection. The Horse Protection Act is amended to require the Department of Agriculture to license, train, and oversee inspectors qualified to detect sore horses at events. Inspectors with unsatisfactory performance may have their license revoked after a hearing. The Horse Protection Act is amended to require the Department of Agriculture to license inspectors to detect sore horses at events. Inspectors must be selected by the Secretary to conduct inspections at horse shows, exhibitions, sales, or auctions. The Horse Protection Act is amended to require licensed inspectors to issue citations for violations and notify the Secretary. Additionally, the heading for subsection (e) is changed from "Appointed" to "Designated". In section 5, paragraph (2) is amended to include causing a horse to become sore for showing or selling purposes. The Horse Protection Act is amended to require licensed inspectors to issue citations for violations and notify the Secretary. Amendments include changing the heading from "Appointed" to "Designated" and specifying the use of action devices on horse limbs. The Horse Protection Act is amended to prohibit the use of action devices or weighted shoes on Tennessee Walking, Racking, or Spotted Saddle horses at shows, exhibitions, or sales. Violations will result in penalties as outlined in the Act. The Horse Protection Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, including fines up to $5,000 and imprisonment for up to three years for each violation. The Horse Protection Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, including fines up to $5,000 and imprisonment for up to three years for each violation. Any person who knowingly fails to obey an order of disqualification shall face fines, imprisonment, or both. The Horse Protection Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, including fines up to $4,000 for failing to pay a licensed inspector hired under section 4(c). The Horse Protection Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, including fines up to $5,000 for repeat offenses and potential permanent disqualification for third or subsequent violations. The Secretary will issue regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment. If any part of the Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act will not be affected.
